English: Portugal, once a monarchy, then a republic, and now a decrepit dictatorship. During the 19th century, the country was marked by the internal struggles between republicans and supporters of a constitutional monarchy, which caused a deep rift in the country. In 1910, a coup by republican officers against Emanuel II abolished the rule of the Royal House of Braganca. Teófilo Fernandes Braga became the first president, proclaiming civil liberties and emancipating women in family law. A land reform programme failed, however, due to opposition from the aristocracy. By 1914, German troops in Africa started harassing Portuguese positions in Angola and Mozambique. Despite the fragile political situation, not to mention strong pro-German sentiment in both public and government, Portugal declared war on the German Empire on March 1916 and allied with the Entente during the Weitkrieg. The CEP - "Corpo Expedicionário Português" ("Portuguese Expeditionary Corps") was formed and dispatched to France in May 1917, participating in the disastrous Battle of the Lys in April 1918. In only four hours of fighting, the Portuguese forces lost over 7.500 men. As news reached Lisbon, a major crisis ensued, as Sidónio Pais carried a coup and overthrew the weak First Republic. The "Nova República" ("New Republic") was established with himself as president, and the Portuguese forces decided shift their efforts from Europe to protection of the African colonies. As the war was over, in 1921, the merchant marine suffered heavy losses from the German U-Boats, and trade with the colonies had collapsed, but the Portuguese colonial empire was left intact due to the Peace with Honour accords. As the country itself was relatively unscathed, Sidónio Pais's popularity and power rose to unprecedented levels, which allowed for a curbing of any possible army revolt. For eight years, he had supreme power in the country, until the rise of Carmona and Salazar. Due to internal power struggles, the duo managed to remove Sidónio Pais from power in mid-1926. After ten years and many crisis and corruption scandals - most blamed on Carmona's weak personality -, and foreign threats in the form of expansionist Mittelafrika and the unstable Spanish government, the New Republic is nothing but a weak dictatorship bearing little to no resemblance to the previous era. With anti-dicatorship sentiment on the rise, the question is no longer IF the regime will fall, but WHEN and WHO shall rise from its ashes. Will the democratic forces assemble and bring stability to the nation? Will the monarchist movement be ready to restore the House of Braganza and bring Portugal back to its path of glory? Are the reactionary forces of the military ready to show their true face and do what the country needs the most? Sidónio Pais may also return to politics, rally the people for his cause and build a regime that will beat the test of time. Even Salazar, if by any luck he survives, will more than likelly create a monster far worse than the New Republic could ever be.

Siberia and the Russian far-east had been major areas of conflict during the Russian Civil War, as the location of a short-lived democratic republic, the rising of the 'Czech legion', and a Japanese intervention. While forced to evacuate their forces due to German pressure (as well as intense resistance from local Cossacks), the Japanese remained eager to extend their influence and in 1922 pushed for the establishment of an independent state in the Transamur region. This motion gained the support of the Vladivostok business community, despite the fact that it left them vulnerable to forming an economic dependency on Japan. The majority of the business community, however, saw economic and diplomatic relations with the rising power in the East as a significant advantage, especially when compared to the alternative of being sucked further into the disorder besetting the rest of Russia. The new nation gained a prominent figurehead in the form of Admiral Kolchak, one of the more successful White Generals of the civil war and the one-time self-proclaimed 'Supreme Ruler of All Russia', who had been forced to flee Russia following his unsuccessful attempt to seize control in 1925. In 1936, the Transamur Republic has become a corporate and militaristic state, and is politically, economically and militarily under the thumb of the Japanese Empire. But Kolchak has goals of his own. Could he simply be playing a very dangerous game, using the Japanese protection to establish his own rule, first over Siberia, and then over Russia as a whole?

When revolution swept through the British Home Isles, it precipitated a much wider and far bloodier social upheaval in the jewel in the crown of British Imperialism, India. In late 1925, the British government reached an accord with a conservative-liberal coalition of Indian civil servants, politicians and princes that resulted in the signing of the Anglo-Indian Treaty, effectively granting India home-rule as a dominion within the British Commonwealth. However, these concessions were too little, too late for the leadership of the Indian National Congress who, inspired by the events in London, convened a provisional government in Calcutta in the Bengal. When the new Indian government in Delhi attempted to enforce its authority against the leftist provisional government, civil war broke out. The war raged across the Gangetic Plain and the Deccan Plateau, becoming ever more furious as the southern princes rebelled against the Delhi government, and British forces began to arrive. However, by 1928 an uneasy truce had descended on the sub-continent as both Calcutta and Delhi were plagued by internal discord and martially exhausted. The truce settled into an armed peace as all three governments (Hyderabad taking on the name of a so-called National Government) began to consolidate their rule and apparatus of state in their respective provinces. The Bhartiya Commune, with its core in the revolutionary tradition of the Bengal, commenced a series of reforms aimed at improving women's and minority rights, abolishing serfdom and landlordism whilst ever standing guard around the legacy of the Indian revolution. Now 10 years after the first Indian Civil War, the three competing states seem to be gathering steam for a new round of conflict over the legacy of the late British Raj.

Although factually independent since 1821, Spain recognized the autonomy of her former colony not until 1871 when a peace between the countries was struck after a conflict of the two countries over the Chinchain Islands. An alliance with Bolivia drew the country 1879 till 1883 in a border conflict between Chile and Bolivia in the Atacama Desert (Saltpeter War). During the war Peru lost her provinces of Tarapacá, Arica, and Tacna. British and U.S. financial circles exploited the opportunity, stripping the weakened Peruvian state of their state railroad, nullifying Peru's debts in exchange. Between 1895 and 1930 the domestic situation was consolidated. Newly discovered copper deposits made up for the loss of the Saltpeter provinces for which Peru was compensated in the Treaty of Lima 1929, getting free port access to Arica, receiving back the province of Tacna, and 6 million Dollars. The socialist APRA (Allianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana, founded in 1924) under Victor Raúl Haya de la Torre demanded a land reform and the political and social integration of the Indios who made up 50 percent of the population. In 1931 and 1936 Haya de la Torre failed in the elections. The successes of his party, however, alarmed the military under Oscar Raimundo Benavides who banned the party.
French: Le Pérou est officiellement indépendant depuis 1821, mais l’Espagne ne reconnaît le nouveau statut de sa colonie qu’en 1871, lorsqu’une paix est signée entre les deux pays à l’issue du conflit qui les opposait pour la possession des îles Chincha. L’alliance avec la Bolivie entraîne le pays dans un conflit frontalier entre le Chili et la Bolivie dans le désert d’Atacama (guerre du Pacifique). Au cours de cette guerre, le Pérou perd les provinces de Tarapacá, d’Arica et de Tacna. Les financiers britanniques et américains profitent de la situation pour déposséder le fragile Etat péruvien de son chemin de fer national en promettant, en échange, d’annuler les dettes du pays. Entre 1895 et 1930, la situation intérieure se stabilise. La découverte de mines de cuivre permet de compenser la perte des provinces péruviennes du salpêtre. A l’issue du traité de Lima de 1929, le pays bénéficie toutefois d’un accès libre au port d’Arica, de la réintégration de la province de Tacna et d’une compensation financière de 6 millions de dollars. La chute du président Leguías après les ravages de la Grande Dépression plonge le pays dans un climat de troubles et de tensions politiques. La parti socialiste de l’APRA (Allianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana), fondé en 1924 et dirigé par Raúl Haya de la Torre, réclame une réforme terrienne ainsi que l’intégration politique et sociale de la population indienne constituant 50 pour cent de la population péruvienne.  Haya de la Torre perd les élections de 1931 et 1936. La popularité de son parti inquiète toutefois le gouvernement militaire dirigé par Oscar Raimundo Benavides qui décide d’interdire le parti.
Italian: Anche se di fatto indipendente dal 1821, la Spagna riconobbe l'autonomia del Perù non prima del 1871, con la pace siglata fra i due paesi alle isole Chinchain. Un'alleanza con la Bolivia, trascinò il paese dal 1879 al 1883 in un conflitto al confine, fra Cile e Bolivia nel deserto Atacama (guerra del salnitro). Durante la guerra, il Perù perse le province di Tarapacá, Arica e Tacna. I circoli finanziari inglesi e americani approfittarono dell'occasione, togliendo al debole stato peruviano la sua ferrovia in cambio dell'azzeramento del debito pubblico. Fra il 1895 e il 1930, la situazione interna si consolidò. La scoperta di nuovi depositi di rame rimpiazzò la perdita delle province del salnitro, per le quali il Perù venne compensato col trattato di Lima (1929), ottenendo libero accesso al porto di Arica e ottenendo la restituzione della provincia di Tacna oltre a 6 milioni di dollari. Con la grande depressione e la conseguente caduta del presidente Leguías, il clima negli affari interni si raffreddò. L'Alleanza Popolare Rivoluzionaria Americana (APRA) socialista, fondata nel 1924 sotto Victor Raúl Haya de la Torre, chiese una riforma della terra e l'integrazione politica e sociale degli Indio, che rappresentavano il 50 percento della popolazione. Nel 1931 e nel 1936, Haya de la Torre non venne eletto. Tuttavia, i successi del suo schieramento allarmarono i militari guidati da Oscar Raimundo Benavides, i quali bandirono il partito.
Spanish: Aunque teóricamente independiente desde 1821, España no reconoció la autonomía de su antigua colonia hasta 1871, cuando se firmó un tratado de paz entre ambos países tras un enfrentamiento por las Islas de Chincha. Una alianza con Bolivia arrastró entre 1879 y 1883 al país a un conflicto fronterizo entre Chile y Bolivia en el desierto de Atacama (la Guerra del Nitrato). Durante esta guerra, Perú perdió las provincias de Tarapacá, Arica y Tacna. Los círculos financieros de Gran Bretaña y Estados Unidos aprovecharon la oportunidad para despojar al estado peruano de sus ferrocarriles estatales, anulando a cambio las deudas que Perú mantenía con ellos. La situación interna se consolidó entre 1895 y 1930. El descubrimiento de nuevos yacimientos de cobre compensó la pérdida de las provincias ricas en nitrato, por las que Perú fue indemnizada en el Tratado de Lima de 1929 con la concesión de acceso portuario libre a Arica, la devolución de la provincia de Tacna y 6 millones de dólares. Con la Gran Depresión y la subsiguiente caída del presidente Leguías, el clima se fue enfriando en la política interior. Los socialistas de la APRA (Alianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana, fundada en 1924), al mando de Víctor Raúl Haya de la Torre, exigieron una reforma agraria y la integración social y política de los indios, que componían el 50 por ciento de la población. Haya de la Torre fracasó en las elecciones de 1931 y 1936. Sin embargo, los éxitos de su partido alarmaron al ejército, al mando de Óscar Raimundo Benavides, que ilegalizó al partido.
German: Trotz ihrer de facto-Unabängigkeit seit 1821 erkannte Spanien die Autonomie seiner früheren Kolonie nicht vor 1871 an, als nach einem Konflikt der beiden Länder um die Chinchain-Inseln ein Frieden zwischen den beiden Ländern geschlossen wurde. Eine Allianz mit Bolivien zog das Land 1879 bis 1883 in einen Grenzkonflikt zwischen Chile und Bolivien in der Atacama-Wüste (Salpeterkrieg) hinein. Während des Krieges verlor Peru seine Provinzen Tarapacá, Arica und Tacna. Britische und amerikanische Finanzkreise nutzen die Gelegenheit, dem geschwächten peruanischen Staat seine Eisenbahn abzunehmen und im Gegenzug Perus Schulden zu annullieren. Zwischen 1895 und 1930 wurde die innenpolitische Situation gefestigt: Neu entdeckte Kupfervorkommen glichen den Verlust der Salpeterprovinzen aus, für den Peru im Abkommen von Lima 1929 entschädigt wurde: Es erhielt freien Hafenzugang zu Arica, bekam die Provinz Tacna wieder, sowie 6 Millionen Dollar. Mit der Großen Depression und dem darauffolgenden Präsidenten Leguías kühlte sich das innenpolitische Klima ab: Die sozialistische APRA (Allianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana, gegründet 1924) unter Victor Raúl Haya de la Torre verlangte eine Landreform und die politische und soziale Integration der Indios, welche 50 Prozent der Bevölkerung ausmachten. 1931 und 1936 verlor Haya de la Torre die Wahlen. Die Erfolge seiner Partei aber alarmierten das Militär unter Oscar Raimundo Benavides, der die Partei verbieten ließ.

English: Following the Union of the Principalities of Wallachia and Moldova under Cuza in 1859, the coronation of a German prince as King Carol I in 1866, and the achievement of complete independence from the Ottoman Empire in 1878, Romania began its slow process of modernization and of turning to the west. In 1913, it entered the Second Balkan War, tipping the balance against Bulgaria and subsequently annexing southern Dobrogea from them. Romania initially remained neutral in the Weltkrieg, but would join the Entente in 1916, led by Carol's successor Ferdinand. After a failed attempt to invade Transylvania, nearly 2/3rds of the country was occupied by the Central Powers. Even though the army fought an effective defensive war from its last remaining holdout in Moldova, the government was forced, following the Russian collapse, to sign the Treaty of Bucharest in 1918, handing over the southern half of the country and having the economy subjugated. The treaty was never ratified and by the end of the Weltkrieg a new treaty consisting of milder terms was drawn. The southern part of Dobrogea was returned to Bulgaria, Oltenia was de-militarized, the oilfields were leased to Germany until 2012, and various other sectors of the economy became dominated by German and Austrian companies, with Romania getting the province of Bessarabia from the fallen Russian Empire in return. After the death of Ferdinand in 1927, the military managed to effectively seize the reigns of government, installing the 6 year old Mihai, Ferdinand’s grandson, as their puppet king, completely bypassing Carol II, the old king’s disgraced son. Of the various political groups the generals co-opted, the extremist right-wing Iron Guard led by Corneliu Zelea Codreanu proved the most dangerous. He and his organization managed in time to acquire more and more power within the state apparatus, co-opting many army generals and other influential leaders, and eventually violently ousting the part of the military government still opposing him in 1935 and setting himself up as head of state, just as the young king fled the country. Codreanu now rules over a divided nation, promising to restore Romania to its former greatness, throw off the shackles of its oppression and be rid of its enemies both foreign and domestic.

English: The Kingdom of Naples had ruled southern Italy up until its annexation into the unified kingdom of Italy in 1860. With the collapse of Italy at the end of the Weltkrieg, the victorious Central Powers chose to resurrect the nation as part of their 'divide and weaken' plan for the peninsula, setting up a puppet king on the throne. Surprisingly for the Austrians, there was much opposition to this plan from the traditionally conservative peasantry, which was so strong as to result in a series of uprisings. At the same time Anarcho-Syndicalist movements began to grow in the new state, and encouraged by events elsewhere in the world became increasingly aggressive. Before long southern Italy was in chaos, a chaos which lasted for the next year and a half. Many Syndicalist leaders in northern Italy, who were unable to act due to the Austrian occupation, migrated south and served to further fuel the growing Syndicalist groups there, and they encouraged political alliances with the anarchists, which allowed them to increase their power greatly. In February 1922, with Austro-Hungary in chaos over the death of Kaiser Karl and his federalization plan, the Anarcho-Syndicalists felt ready to launch the revolution. They were joined by large parts of the deeply discontent peasantry, who saw it primarily as a chance to rid southern Italy of Austrian influences. After two months of civil war, the Anarcho-Syndicalists triumphed – the ‘Socialist Republic of Italy’ was declared in April 1922, and an alliance with France forged. With Germany’s refusal to intervene, Austria was grudgingly forced to recognise the new regime. In the 15 years since the Republic’s founding it has slowly rebuilt and attempted to industrialise itself, strengthening its economy and military as it plans how best to reunify Italy.

After the October Revolution, various Anti-Bolshevik forces began to consolidate all over the former Russian Empire, eventually leading to a massive rebellion against the Soviet Republic both in Siberia and in the Don and Kuban steppes in the middle of 1918. The White forces made considerable gains, but the Red Army was still too strong and well placed, dominating Russia's industrial heartland and transportation networks. Fortunately the German Empire, fearing the success of such a dangerous ideology, intervened on behalf of the Whites in exchange for recognition of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk. By September 1920, both Moscow and Petrograd had fallen to the White forces and a new Russian Republic was established in the old Imperial capital of Petrograd. For the past fifteen years the leading parties, the Social Revolutionaries and Kadets, have governed in an uneasy coalition under Kerensky, maintaining their power through electoral manipulation and a lack of serious political opposition. But Russia is becoming increasingly unstable, and other political forces are growing. The time has come for a change so that the country may once again assert itself as a world power...

Since its declaration of independence from Spain in 1821, El Salvador has been sharply divided between liberal and conservative factions that would leave it as disunited as most of the other Central American states. Despite several abandoned attempts to create a federal state with the other Central American countries, El Salvador has remained independent and easily influenced by foreign powers. Indeed, one of the most powerful influences in its history has been the foreign owned coffee industry. A drastic fall in the price of coffee during the great depression would lead to a minor communist insurrection in 1932. In reaction to this insurrection the military seized power and launched a series of reprisals that would claim the lives of over 20,000 Salvadorans. The new President, General Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez would launch a program that can only be described as limited liberalization combined with absolute repression. Though Martinez would never take on the elites of Salvadoran society, he did institute limited land reform and social welfare. A fervent anti-communist, he was sympathetic to the fascist cause, but also deeply aware that the US is much, much closer. The Generalissimo was also known for his spiritualism, which culminated in his stringing lights through San Salvador in an effort to ward off an epidemic of smallpox.
French: Le Salvador se libère officiellement de l’emprise espagnole en 1921. Comme pour la plupart de ses voisins, l’indépendance a engendré dans le pays des conflits opposant mouvements libéraux et conservateurs. Le Salvador essaie à plusieurs reprises de créer un Etat fédéral en s’unissant à d’autres pays d’Amérique centrale. Toutes ses tentatives se soldent toutefois par un échec, laissant le jeune pays en proie aux influences étrangères. La principale influence que subit le pays est imposée par les propriétaires étrangers de l’industrie du café. La chute des prix du café pendant la Grande Dépression est à l’origine d’une révolte communiste en 1932. Les militaires contrecarrent la révolte en accaparant le pouvoir et lancent un programme de représailles qui coûtera la vie plus de 20000 Salvadoriens. Le général Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez, nouveau président du pays, lance un programme politique qui combine la réduction  des libertés civiques à la répression absolue.  Bien que Martinez rechigne à s’attaquer aux élites salvadoriennes, il finit par procéder à des réformes terriennes et établit un système de sécurité sociale. En tant qu’anti-communiste primaire, il se sent proche de la cause fasciste mais reste conscient de la très grande proximité des Etats-Unis. Le généralissimo est également célèbre pour sa pratique du spiritisme dont l’une des principales manifestations a consisté à accrocher des lampions dans toute la ville de San Salvador dans le but de parer à une épidémie de petite vérole.
Italian: Dopo la dichiarazione d'indipendenza dalla Spagna (1821), El Salvador si è trovato bruscamente diviso fra fazioni liberali e conservatrici, che l'avrebbero lasciato disunito come la maggior parte degli altri stati dell'America Centrale. Nonostante diversi tentativi isolati di creare uno stato federale con gli altri paesi centroamericani, El Salvador conservò la propria indipendenza e fu facilmente influenzato dalle potenze straniere. Effettivamente, una delle più potenti influenze nella sua storia fu la presenza di una industria del caffè posseduta da stranieri. Una drastica caduta del prezzo del caffè durante la grande depressione, portò a una piccola insurrezione comunista nel 1932. In risposta a questa insurrezione, i militari presero il potere e lanciarono una serie di rappresaglie che causarono la morte di 20.000 salvadoregni. Il nuovo presidente, il generale Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez, avviò un programma che poteva essere descritto solamente come una sorta di apparente liberalizzazione, negata da una repressione assoluta. Anche se Martinez non sarebbe mai andato contro l'elite della società salvadoregna, egli attuò riforme della terra e per il benessere sociale limitate. Essendo un fervente anticomunista, Martinez simpatizzava per la causa fascista, ma era anche consapevole dell'estrema vicinanza degli Stati Uniti. Il Generalissimo era noto anche per il suo spiritualismo, che culminò con l'affissione di una serie di luci per San Salvador nel tentativo di cacciare un'epidemia di vaiolo.
Spanish: Desde su declaración de independencia de España en 1821, El Salvador ha estado claramente dividido en facciones liberales y conservadoras que lo dejarían tan desunido como la mayoría de los demás estados centroamericanos. Pese a varios intentos abandonados de crear un estado federal con los otros países centroamericanos, El Salvador ha seguido siendo independiente y especialmente vulnerable a influencias de potencias extranjeras. De hecho, una de las más poderosas de su historia ha sido la industria cafetera, en manos extranjeras. Una drástica caída del precio del café durante la Gran Depresión llevaría a una insurrección comunista en 1932, poco trascendente. Reaccionando a esta rebelión, el ejército se hizo con el poder y lanzó una serie de represalias que costarían la vida a más de 20.000 salvadoreños. El nuevo presidente, el general Maximiliano Hernández Martínez, inició un programa de algo que no puede describirse más que como una liberalización limitada con una represión absoluta. Aunque Martínez nunca se enfrentaría a la elite de la sociedad salvadoreña, sí que instauró una reforma agraria restringida y una seguridad social. El general era un ferviente anticomunista que simpatizaba con la causa fascista, pero también era consciente de que los Estados Unidos estaban muchísimo más cerca. El Generalísimo también era conocido por su afición al espiritismo, que culminó con la instalación de cadenas de luces por todo San Salvador en un intento de parar una epidemia de viruela.
German: Seit der Erklärung seiner Unabhängigkeit von Spanien im Jahre 1821 gibt es in El Salvador eine scharfe Trennung zwischen den liberalen und konservativen Fraktionen, wodurch es genauso zersplittert ist wie die meisten anderen zentralamerikanischen Staaten. Trotz mehrerer aufgegebener Versuche, mit anderen Staaten Zentralamerikas einen Bundesstaat zu gründen, ist El Salvador weiterhin unabhängig und lässt sich leicht von ausländischen Mächten beeinflussen. Tatsächlich stellt die Kaffeeindustrie, die sich in ausländischer Hand befindet, einen der größten Einflussfaktoren in seiner Geschichte dar. Ein drastischer Preisverfall für Kaffee im Zuge der Großen Depression führte 1932 zu einem kleineren Aufstand der Kommunisten. Als Reaktion auf diesen Aufstand riss das Militär die Macht an sich. Die folgenden Repressalien forderten das Leben von über 20.000 Salvadorianern. Der neue Präsident, General Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez, startete ein Programm, das wohl nur als “eingeschränkte Befreiung bei absoluter Unterdrückung” beschrieben werden kann. Obwohl sich Martinez niemals mit der Elite der salvadorianischen Gesellschaft anlegte, leitete er dennoch eine limitierte Landreform und ein Sozialsystem ein. Als fanatischer Gegner des Kommunismus sympathisierte er mit dem Faschismus, war sich jedoch der geografischen Lage zu den USA mehr als bewusst. Der Generalissimus war außerdem für seinen Spiritismus bekannt, der darin gipfelte, dass er ganz San Salvador zum Aufhalten einer Pockenepidemie mit aufgereihten Lichtern erleuchten ließ.

English: South Africa has had a long and complicated history. Originally founded by the Dutch, the Cape Colony was annexed by the British in 1806. The British started to settle the eastern border of the colony, with the arrival in Port Elizabeth of the 1820 Settlers. They also began to introduce the first rudimentary rights for the Cape's Black African population and, in 1833, abolished slavery. The resentment that the Dutch farmers (Boers) felt against this social change, as well as the imposition of English language and culture, caused them to migrate inland en masse. This was known as the Great Trek, and the migrating Afrikaners settled inland, forming the ‘Boer Republics’ of Transvaal and the Orange Free State. In spite of this the interior of South Africa remained largely unsettled by whites well into the 19th century, although the region saw endemic conflict between the various native kingdoms and the Boers. This changed upon the discovery of vast diamond and gold deposits in the area. The influx of British prospectors soon led to increasingly violent confrontations between British colonials and Boer Republicans. The period also saw the final, violent repressions of the last remaining free chiefdoms in South Africa, the remainder becoming British protectorates. In an attempt at introducing a federal system, which had been successfully adopted in Canada, incorporating both the colonies and the Boer Republics was shattered by a Boer victory over the British at Majuba in 1881. The resulting Anglo-Boer War raged from 1899 till 1902. Despite financial and diplomatic support from Europe (Germany in particular supplied the Boers with weapons including Krupp guns) and a fierce guerrilla campaign – the British response to which devastated the Afrikaner population, the war ultimately led to the annexation of the Boer Republics. The Boers, however, won the peace, ensuring the new constitution of the Union of South Africa (1910) preserved the retention of white-only rule in South Africa (the Cape and Natal provinces kept coloured and native voting via a qualified franchise, at least in principle if not in practice). The Weltkrieg reopened fresh wounds as many questioned whether to join Britain in its fight against their former ally Germany, while the Union ultimately followed Britain to war, the decision led to the Maritz Rebellion. The war in Africa saw victory in German South-West Africa but frustration as forces under Jan Smuts failed to capture the elusive German General von Lettow-Vorbeck in East Africa.  The Peace with Honour saw the loss of all of South Africa’s gains and the growth of social unrest within the Union (epitomised by the Rand Revolt of 1922). Although returned as Liberal Prime Minister in 1921, Jan Smuts was unable to manage the post war recession and in 1924 the rising discontent with the government led to his defeat by a coalition of the pro-Afrikaner National Party and the socialist South African Labour Party. James Hertzog, the leader of the National Party and former Boer general, became the new Prime Minister of South Africa. Hertzog encouraged the development of the Afrikaner culture and was determined to resist British influence. Increasing tension between South Africa and the British Empire were soon overtaken by events. The British Revolution of 1925 was Hertzog’s chance – his coalition declared a South African Republic and abandoned the Entente, annexing the neighbouring British protectorates of South Rhodesia, Bechuanaland, Lesotho and Swaziland although this decision has been heavily contested after much of the neighbouring regions fell into German hands after the British Revolution. Hertzog continued to rule South Africa as its first President, edging out his coalition partners Labour in 1929 by implementing populist policies which appealed to the working class Afrikaner vote. Opposition to his regime now is headed by the Dominion Party of Jan Smuts, which works for a reconciliation with the Royal Family and the Entente and an expansion of the qualified franchise. Hertzog must now deal with an economy that is overly dependent on the German market as well as face off both rising native unrest and a resurgent British Empire if South Africa is going to endure the years to come.
French: Depuis des milliers d’années, l’Afrique du Sud est partagée entre deux ethnies : les San (bushmen) chasseurs-cueilleurs et les agriculteurs Khoikhoi (Hottentots). La vie paisible de ses communautés ethniques est irrémédiablement détruite par l’installation, en 1652, de bases hollandaises au Cap. Les Khoikhoi sont immédiatement réduits au rang d’esclaves au service des nouveaux arrivants et de la Compagnie hollandaise des Indes orientales qui leur infligent les pires sévices. A l’issue des guerres napoléoniennes, la colonie est récupérée par les Britanniques, dont quelques-uns tenteront, sans grands résultats, de limiter l’asservissement des Khoikhoi. Quoi qu’il en soit, les politiques libérales des colons britanniques poussent la plupart des Voortrekker hollandais à migrer vers le nord et à fonder de nouvelles républiques sur les terres Khoikhoi. L’intérieur des terres sud-africaines reste toutefois à l’abri de l’invasion blanche jusqu’au début du 19e siècle.  La tendance est inversée par la découverte de mines d’or et de diamants dans la région. L’afflux de chercheurs d’or britanniques conduit rapidement à des conflits entre colons anglais et républicains boers. A la même période, de violentes répressions détruisent également les derniers territoires tribaux du pays. La victoire des Boers sur les Britanniques à Majuba, en 1881, met fin à la tentative de construire un Etat fédéral incluant à la fois les colonies et les républiques boers. La guerre anglo-boer qui s’ensuit (1899-1902) conduit finalement à l’annexion des républiques boers. Les Hollandais remportent la victoire et rédigent une constitution qui assure le maintient des lois ségrégationnistes en Afrique du Sud. Les Afrikaners (blancs) restent toutefois très méfiants à l’égard de l’empire britannique.  Une grande partie de la population continue à s’opposer à la colonisation de l’Afrique du Sud malgré l’accord signé avec la couronne en 1926 qui intègre la région au Commonwealth.
Italian: Per migliaia d'anni, il Sud Africa fu popolato da due distinti gruppi culturali i San (boscimani), cacciatori e coltivatori, e i rurali Khoikhoi (ottentotti). Nel 1652, queste comunità vennero irreversibilmente distrutte dall'arrivo di basi olandesi sul promontorio, alle quali seguirono velocemente degli insediamenti. I Khoikhoi vennero presto costretti a lavorare per i colonizzatori e la compagnia delle indie orientali olandese, spesso con meno diritti di quelli degli schiavi americani. Dopo che gli inglesi assunsero il controllo della colonia durante le guerre napoleoniche, furono fatti diversi tentativi per migliorare la condizione dei Khoikhoi, con scarso successo. A ogni modo, le politiche liberali dell'Inghilterra portarono numerosi Voortrekkers olandesi a spostarsi a nord per stabilire le loro repubbliche su altra terra Khoikhoi. Tuttavia, la parte interna del Sud Africa sarebbe rimasta largamente disabitata dai bianchi per buona parte del diciannovesimo secolo. Tutto ciò sarebbe cambiato con la scoperta di vasti giacimenti di oro e diamanti nella zona. L'afflusso di prospettori inglesi avrebbe presto portato a scontri sempre più violenti fra i coloniali inglesi e i repubblicani olandesi. Quel periodo vide, inoltre, le ultime, violente repressioni degli ultimi dignitari liberi in Sud Africa. Il tentativo di istituire un sistema federale che comprendesse sia le colonie che le repubbliche boere, venne infranto dalla vittoria dei boeri sugli inglesi a Majuba nel 1881. La conseguente guerra anglo-boera (1899-1902), avrebbe portato all'annessione delle repubbliche boere. I boeri, tuttavia, avrebbero vinto la pace, creando una costituzione che assicurava il mantenimento in Sud Africa di un governo di soli bianchi. Nonostante ciò, gli Afrikaner bianchi conservarono ancora un grande risentimento nei confronti dell'impero britannico, il cui governo fu persino costretto a sopprimere una rivolta minore contro la guerra con la Germania nel 1914. Anche se nel 1926 venne raggiunto un accordo con la corona che sanciva l'appartenenza del Sud Africa al Commonwealth, c'era ancora una larga fetta della popolazione che si opponeva a questa misura.
Spanish: Durante miles de años, Sudáfrica ha estado habitada por dos grupos culturales diferenciados: los cazadores-recolectores 'san' (bosquimanos) y los agricultores 'khoikhoi' (hotentotes). Estas comunidades fueron destruidas de manera irreversible por la fundación en 1652 de bases holandesas en el cabo que fueron seguidas rápidamente por asentamientos. Los khoikhoi se vieron pronto reducidos a realizar trabajos forzados para los colonos y para la Compañía Holandesa de las Indias Orientales, a menudo con menos derechos de los que tenían los esclavos en las Américas. Después de que los británicos se hiciesen con el control de la colonia durante las Guerras Napoleónicas, hubo varios intentos de mitigar la situación de los khoikhoi, con escaso éxito. En cualquier caso, la política liberal de los británicos empujó a muchos 'voortekkers' (pioneros) holandeses a emigrar al norte y fundar sus propias repúblicas en otros territorios de los khoikhoi. Sin embargo, el interior de Sudáfrica seguiría sin ser colonizado por los blancos hasta bien entrado el siglo XX. Todo esto cambiaría con el descubrimiento de unos inmensos depósitos de oro y diamantes en la región. La oleada de prospectores británicos pronto llevaría a enfrentamientos cada vez más violentos entre colonos británicos y republicanos bóers. Este periodo también vio las últimas y violentas represiones de los únicos cacicatos libres que quedaban en Sudáfrica. Un intento de integrar tanto a las colonias como a las repúblicas de los bóers mediante un sistema federal fue hecho añicos por una victoria de éstos sobre los británicos en Majuna en 1881. La resultante guerra Anglo-bóer, que discurrió entre 1899 y 1902, llevaría a una anexión de las repúblicas bóer. Sin embargo, los bóers ganarían la paz, creando una constitución que aseguraba el control de Sudáfrica por parte de los blancos. Sin embargo, los afrikáners blancos seguían albergando un gran resentimiento hacia el Imperio Británico. Aunque en 1926 se llegó a un acuerdo con la corona que aseguraba que Sudáfrica seguiría formando parte de la Commonwealth, gran parte de la población sigue oponiéndose a esta medida.
German: Seit Tausenden von Jahren wird Südafrika von zwei unterschiedlichen kulturellen Gruppen bevölkert, nämlich den San (Buschmännern), die Jäger und Sammler waren, sowie den agrarischen Khoikhoi (Hottentotten). Diese Gemeinschaften wurden 1652 durch die Errichtung holländischer Stützpunkte, denen kurz darauf Siedlungen folgten, unwiederbringlich zerstört. Die Khoikhoi wurden schon bald zu Sklaven der Siedler und der holländischen East India Company erniedrigt und hatten oft viel weniger Rechte als die Sklaven in Nord- und Südamerika. Nach der britischen Übernahme der Kolonie während der napoleonischen Kriege wurden - mit wenig Erfolg - mehrere Versuche zur Linderung der Not der Khoikhoi unternommen. Jedenfalls zog die liberale Politik der Briten eine große Anzahl holländischer Voortrekkers (Pioniere) nach Norden, die sich bei der Errichtung eigener Republik weitere Ländereien der Khoikhoi aneigneten. Das Innere Südafrikas sollte jedoch bis weit ins 19. Jahrhundert von Weißen weitgehend unbesiedelt bleiben. Dies änderte sich, nachdem in diesem Gebiet gewaltige Edelstein- und Goldvorkommen entdeckt wurden. Durch den Zuzug britischer Goldschürfer kam es schon bald zu gewalttätigen Auseinandersetzungen zwischen britischen Kolonisten und burischen Republikanern. In diesen Zeitraum fielen ebenfalls die abschließenden, gewaltsamen Unterdrückungen der letzten freien Häuptlingsstämme Südafrikas. Der Versuch, sowohl die Kolonien als auch die Burenrepubliken in einem Föderationssystem zusammenzufassen, wurde vom Sieg der Buren über die Engländer bei Majuba im Jahr 1881 vereitelt. Der darauffolgende Burenkrieg von 1899-1902 führte zur Annektierung der Burenrepubliken. Die Buren gingen jedoch siegreich aus den Friedensverhandlungen hervor, da eine Verfassung verabschiedet wurde, welche die Beibehaltung der weißen Alleinherrschaft in Südafrika gewährleistete. Weiße Afrikaner hatten gegenüber dem britischen Königreich dennoch weiterhin starke Vorbehalte: Die britische Regierung sah sich 1914 sogar gezwungen, einen kleineren Aufstand wegen des Kriegs gegen Deutschland niederzuschlagen. Obwohl man 1926 mit der Krone ein Abkommen getroffen hat, laut dem Südafrika ein Teil des Commonwealth bleiben soll, ist ein Großteil der Bevölkerung weiterhin gegen diese Maßnahme.

English: Under the control of regional powers such as Egypt and the Ottoman Empire through most of its history, the Kingdom of Hejaz gained political independence in the early 20th century. It was one of several regions of the Ottoman Empire provoked into rebellion by T. E. Lawrence ("of Arabia") of the British during the Weltkrieg. In 1916, its independence was proclaimed by Hussein bin Ali, the Sharif of Mecca. Their hopes of freeing the Arabs north of them were curtailed by Britain's diversion of forces from the region and Ottoman propaganda campaigns after the Sykes-Pycot agreement was publicized by the Bolsheviks. When the British fell back past the Sinai and Mesopotamia after the Peace with Honour, the Arab revolters decided to make their stand in the region of Nejd and its capital, Riyadh. The Ottoman forces, strained after many years of war, were unable to overcome the Arab fighters and in the end a separate armistice was signed where the Kingdoms of Nejd and Hejaz were recognized as independent states. Soon after that, bin Ali was able to gain control over Nejd, annexing it to Hejaz in 1922. Thanks to the protection of Egypt, Hejaz has been able to survive until the present, and the decline of the Ottoman Empire may allow another attempt to free the Arabs still living under the Ottoman rule.
French: Le centre de la péninsule arabique est le point de départ de l’Etat wahhabite formé en 1744. Mouhammad ibn Abd-al Wahhab estime que l’islam chiite pratiqué dans l’Empire ottoman et l’islam sunnite de Perse sont tous deux des déformations de ce qu’est véritablement la foi musulmane. Grâce à l’aide de Mouhammad Ibn Saud, les Wahhabites lancent une attaque qui va durer des décennies mais qui leur permet de conquérir toutes les tribus d’Arabie. A la mort d’Abd-al Wahhab, les Saudis règnent sur la majeure partie de la péninsule et dominent en 1806 la Mecque et la Syrie. Le gouverneur ottoman d’Egypte, Méhémet Ali, écrase sur ordre du sultan le premier Etat saoudien en 1818. Dès 1824, une nouvelle principauté se forme sous le gouvernement saoudien. La secte wahhabite reste un pouvoir politique et religieux très important en Arabie. En 1843, une tentative de réhabilitation de l’Etat wahhabite est déjouée par les querelles entre tribus et, en 1884, par l’intervention ottomane. Les derniers Saudis fuient en 1891 vers le Koweït où Aziz Ibn Saud (1902-1953) fonde un nouvel Etat wahhabite. Il conquiert Riyad en 1902 pour en faire sa capitale. Saud doit toutefois se soumettre à une expédition militaire ottomane, en 1905, tout en conservant son statut de vassal. Le traité Saudi-Ottoman de 1914 attribue la province de Nedjd aux saoudiens et Ibn Saud reste calme après la signature du traité de protection mutuelle avec les Britanniques. Les plus actifs dans la bataille contre les Turcs sont les Hachémites de Hedjaz. Le shérif Hussein s’autoproclame “roi des pays arabes” après que les Turcs ont été expulsés de Médine et devient dès lors la principale menace au pouvoir en place. Les Hachémites sont cependant chassés de Hedjaz par les Saudis en 1924 qui proclameront, dès 1927, Ibn Saud “roi de Nedjd, de Hedjaz et de ses protectorats”. En 1932, Saud devient le dirigeant de l’Arabie Saoudite. Les Saudis deviennent peu à peu les gardiens des lieux saints de l’islam, un rôle qui contribue à légitimer leur souveraineté et les revenus qu’ils perçoivent des pèlerinages. Pourtant les problèmes économiques résultant de la Grande Dépression contraignent les Saudis à ouvrir leurs frontières aux concessions pétrolières américaines. Les puits pétroliers découverts en 1936 ne sont rentabilisés que dix ans plus tard.
Italian: Il centro della penisola arabica divenne il punto di partenza dello stato Wahhabite nel 1744. Fo Muhammad ibn Abd-al Wahhâb ritenne che sia l'Islam sciita dell'impero Ottomano che quello sunnita fossero delle alterazioni persiane della vera fede musulmana. Insieme a Muhammad Ibn Saud, i wahhabiti conquistarono tutte le tribù dell'Arabia grazie a un'offensiva che durò decenni. Dopo la morte di Abd-al Wahhâb, i sauditi governarono la parte più grande della penisola, conquistando La Mecca nel 1806 e minacciando la Siria. Mohammed Ali, il governatore ottomano in Egitto, abbatté il primo stato saudita nel 1818 su ordine del sultano, ma già nel 1824 venne formato un nuovo principato sotto il governo saudita. Il Wahhabiyya rimase un importante potere religioso e politico in Arabia. Nel 1843, un tentativo di ripristinare lo stato wahhabita fu sventato dai dissensi fra le tribù e l'intervento dell'impero Ottomano nel 1884. L'ultimo Saud fuggì in Kuwait nel 1891. Da lì, Aziz ibn Saud (1902-1953) riesce a fondare un nuovo paese wahhabita. Nel 1902, egli conquistò Ryad e ne fece la capitale del suo stato. Dovette, tuttavia, soccombere a una spedizione militare ottomana nel 1905, pur riuscendo a mantenere lo status di vassallo. Nel trattato ottomano-saudita del 1914, Aziz ibn Saud ricevette la provincia di Nadshd come proprietà ereditaria. Dopo il trattato di protezione anglo-saudita del 1915 Ibn Saud rimase tranquillo. Il ruolo attivo nello scontro con i turchi fu tenuto dagli Heshamite di Hedjaz. Sherif Hussein, che si auto-proclamò 'Re delle terre arabe' dopo la cacciata dei Turchi da Medina, era diventato il principale rivale per la lotta al potere. Tuttavia, dopo la guerra mondiale, gli Hashemite vennero espulsi da Hedjaz dai sauditi nel 1924 e nel 1927, Ibn Saud venne incoronato 'Re di Nadshd, Hedjaz e dei loro protettorati'. Nel 1932, egli diventò il capo della neonata Arabia Saudita. Diventare i custodi dei luoghi sacri dell'Islam diede ai sauditi sia un'importante legittimazione della loro sovranità che grosse entrate dai pellegrinaggi. Ad ogni modo, le battute d'arresto dell'economia, dovute alla grande depressione, costrinsero il paese ad aprirsi alle concessioni petrolifere americane. Nonostante tutto, i pozzi petroliferi scoperti nel 1936, sarebbero diventati importanti economicamente solo un decennio dopo.
Spanish: El centro de la Península Arábiga se convirtió en el punto de partida del estado wahabí en 1744. Para Muhammad ibn Abd-al Wahhab, tanto el islamismo chiíta del Imperio Otomano como el suní de los persas eran distorsiones de la verdadera fe musulmana. Aliados con Muhammad Ibn Saud, los wahabíes conquistaron a todas las tribus de Arabia en una ofensiva que duraría décadas. Tras la muerte de Abd-al Wahhab, los saudís controlaban la mayor parte de la península, conquistando La Meca en 1806 y amenazando a Siria. Mohammed Alí, gobernador otomano de Egipto, aplastó el primer estado saudí en 1818 por orden del sultán. Pero ya en 1824 se empezó a formar un nuevo principado gobernado por los saudís. Los wahabíes siguieron siendo una importante potencia religiosa y política en Arabia. En 1843, un intento de restaurar el estado wahabí se vio frustrado por rencillas entre las tribus y la intervención otomana de 1884. El último Saúd huyó a Kuwait en 1891. Desde allí, Aziz ibn Saúd (1902-1953) consiguió fundar un nuevo estado wahabí. En 1902 conquistó Riad y la convirtió en su capital. Tuvo que rendirse ante una expedición militar otomana en 1905, pero mantuvo la condición de vasallo. En el tratado saudí-otomano de 1914, recibió la provincia de Nadshd como propiedad hereditaria. Tras el tratado de protección británico-saudí de 1915, Ibn Saúd permaneció tranquilo. EL papel activo en la lucha contra los turcos fue adoptado por los hashemitas del Hedjaz. Sherif Hussein, que se proclamó 'rey de tierras árabes' tras la expulsión de los turcos de Medina, se convirtió en el principal rival en la lucha por el poder. Sin embargo, tras la Guerra Mundial, los hashemitas fueron expulsados de Hedjaz por los saudís en 1924, y en 1927 Ibn Saúd fue coronado 'rey de Nadshd, Hedjaz y sus Protectorados'. En 1932 se convirtió en el soberano del nuevo estado de Arabia Saudí. El hecho de convertirse en los guardianes de los Lugares Sagrados del Islam proporcionó a los saudís legitimidad para su poder y grandes ingresos provenientes de las peregrinaciones. Sin embargo, los reveses económicos debidos a la Gran Depresión les forzaron a abrir el país a las concesiones petrolíferas estadounidenses. Pero los yacimientos petrolíferos descubiertos en 1936 no serían importantes económicamente hasta más de una década después.
German: Der Zentrum der arabischen Halbinsel wurde im Jahr 1744 zum Ausgangspunkt des Wahabitenstaats. Für Muhammad ibn Abd-al Wahhâb stellte sowohl der schiitische Islam des Osmanischen Reichs als auch der sunnitische Islam der Perser eine Verzerrung des muslimischen Glaubens dar. Zusammen mit Muhammad Ibn Saud besiegten die Wahhabiten in einem jahrzehntelangen Feldzug sämtliche arabischen Stämme. Nach dem Tod von Abd-al Wahhâb herrschten die Saudis über den größeren Teil der Halbinsel, eroberten 1806 Mekka und bedrohten Syrien. Der erste saudische Staat wurde 1818 auf Befehl des Sultans von Mohammed Ali, dem osmanischen Gouverneur Ägyptens, zerschlagen. Doch bereits 1824 bildete sich unter der saudischen Regierung ein neues Fürstentum. Wahhabiyya blieb in der arabischen Welt eine wichtige religiöse und politische Macht. 1843 wurde ein Versuch, den Wahabitenstaat wiederaufstehen zu lassen, durch Stammesstreitigkeiten und die osmanische Intervention von 1884 verhindert. Die letzten Saudis flohen im Jahr 1891 nach Kuwait. Von dort aus gelang es Aziz ibn Saud (1902 - 1953), ein neues wahabitisches Land zu gründen. 1902 eroberte er Ryad und machte es zu seiner Hauptstadt. Zwar musste er sich 1905 einer osmanischen Militärexpedition unterwerfen, behielt jedoch den Status eines Vasallen. Im saudisch-osmanischen Vertrag von 1914 erhielt er die Provinz Nadshd als erblichen Besitz. Nach dem britisch-saudischen Schutzvertrag von 1915 verhielt Ibn Saud sich inaktiv. Die aktive Rolle im Kampf gegen die Türken wurden von Haschemiten aus dem Hedjaz übernommen. Sherif Hussein, der sich nach der Vertreibung der Türken aus Medina selbst zum 'König der arabischen Länder' ernannte, wurde für ihn zum größten Rivalen um die Macht. Nach dem Ersten Weltkrieg wurden die Haschemiten 1924 von den Saudis aus dem Hedjaz verbannt. 1927 krönte man Ibn Saud zum 'König von Nadshd, Hedjaz und ihren Protektoraten'. 1932 wurde er zum Herrscher des neu gegründeten Saudi-Arabiens. Ihre Aufsicht über die heiligen Stätten des Islams verschaffte den Saudis eine wichtige Legitimierung ihrer Herrschaft und ein hohes Einkommen durch Pilger. Durch wirtschaftliche Rückschläge im Zuge der Großen Depression sahen sie sich jedoch gezwungen, Ölkonzessionen an die USA zu vergeben. Trotzdem wurden die 1936 entdeckten Ölquellen erst über ein Jahrzehnt später wirtschaftlich bedeutend.

English: The Swiss Confederation saw much crisis in 19th century. In several cantons liberal powers prevailed, calling for more democracy and centralism. This met the opposition of the catholic, conservatively dominated cantons who formed the Sonderbund in 1845. The Sonderbund War erupted in 1847 which saw the liberals as victors. In 1848 a Federal Constitution was ratified, turning the loose league of cantons into a Federal Stae with a new federal capital in Bern. The new constitution created new institutions like the (Bundesrat) Federal Council, Bundesversammlung (Federal Assebly), and Bundesgericht (Federal Court). Switzerland remained neutral during Weltkrieg, although there were various domestic conflicts between German and French speaking Swiss citizens. In addition economical problems arose, completely surrounded as the country was by warring nations. The radical left gained a lot of support during that time, and in 1918 a strike in Geneva called for by the workers movement attempted to push through major social changes. The attempt failed because of the fear of spreading of French syndicalism and its subsequent repression by Swiss government, but in its wake social reforms were begun, bringing about higher wages and shorter work days. In 1919 a system of proportional representation was introduced. The conservative Freisinnige lost their majority while the social democrats grew stronger. Into the 1930s domestic politics were governed in response to the conflict between social democrats and conservatives. The struggles between communities in Switzerland are now taking on more political values: French-speakers are more socialist, Germans more conservative and Italians more clerical. Will the rising belligerence in Europe have consequences for the neutral Confederation?

The assassination of the Archduke Ferdinand by a Serb nationalist in 1914 proved to be the catalyst that began the Weltkrieg. Despite expecting an easy campaign, Austrian forces only managed to occupy Serbia itself in late 1915, and only then because of the entrance of Bulgaria into the war. After the war Serbia’s southern territories were handed over to Bulgaria, whilst the remainder was kept under Austrian occupation until 1922, when the Austrians were forced to withdraw their troops due to ethnic tensions elsewhere in the Empire – but only after setting up a new government formed from ex-collaborators. Since then Serbia has struggled to survive, keeping a low profile in light of the knowledge that she could not stand up to any sort of military attack. Over time however, the government has become increasingly anti-Austrian and jingoistic, and knowing that they could not hope to defeat Austria, they have turned their attentions southwards, towards the lands occupied by Bulgaria. Several diplomatic talks have already been conducted with the Romanian and Greek governments (who also lost territory to Bulgaria) with a view to undermining Bulgarian hegemony in the region, and some say talk of a formal alliance is not far off. Can Serbia successfully steer a course to triumph in the ‘Bulgarian Matter’? And if so, can she finally defeat the old enemy Austria, and realise her dream of a pan-Slavic Union?

Siam is one of the few countries that gained from the German victory in the Weltkrieg without actually joining the Central Powers. When the French were forced to cede French Indochina to Germany, the Kaiser gave Siam the lands stolen by the french years before. When the 1925 British Revolution broke out, the Kaiser let Siam take part of the lands of former British Malaysia. Finally, in 1929, when Germany brought an end to the hostilities in Burma, the imposed treaty awarded the eastern part of Burma to Siam. In the last 20 years the kingdom has greatly increased its territory and became a stable and peaceful country. However, many think that the German Empire is in decline and Siam should not expect any more favours, but should start to build its defences in case the syndicalists or one of its neighbours (Burma and Yunnan above all) try to conquer it.

Siberian territory has always attracted thousands of settlers, who wanted to start a new life, sought refuge from the government or just had a spirit of adventure. This land, distant from the central Russia, used to be one the most important centres of the resistance against the Bolshevik government in 1918. Now, when the political situation in Russia is again complicated, the representatives of the different Siberian cities and towns have decided to declare independence and save their land from the destructive war in the West.

Sinkiang played a crucial role in the The Great Game between the region's major powers, located as it was between Russia and British India. Both powers soon became active in trading in the province, although the Manchus had imposed a ban on European trade in the area. According to a Russian source, 'the British, with their record in India, were the more dreaded of the two, and Peking lived in constant fear of intrigue in East Turkestan by these inveterate colonizers.' However, despite British efforts, Russia eventually gained the upper hand in the area. As a result of a number of the 'unequal treaties' which China was forced to sign with the Western powers after the Opium Wars, specifically the Ili Treaty (1851), the Tacheng Protocol of the Treaty of Peking (1860), and the Treaty of Tarbagatai (1864), China had to surrender nearly 350,000 square miles of territory to Russia, as well as giving the Russians special trading privileges and the right to station consuls in the area. At the same time, China suffered massive territorial losses to the Russians in Manchuria.China's weakened state as a result of the Taiping Rebellion (1850-64), the second Opium War (1857-60), and Muslim Rebellions in Yunnan (1855-1873) and Shaanxi (1862-1873) set the stage for the next phase in the Game. Between 1864 and 1877, the Muslims in Sinkiang revolted and set up an independent state, which came to be known as 'Kashgaria,' under the leadership of the Kokand adventurer Yaqub Beg, who attempted to maintain good relations with both Britain and Russia, in hopes that they would be able to protect him against the inevitable Chinese attempt to once again bring the area and its inhabitants under the control of the Qing dynasty. Under these unstable conditions, the Russians proceeded to annex the Ili Valley in 1870-71, giving as their reason the need to maintain law and order in this area adjacent to their newly-conquered territory in Russian Turkestan. In 1877, Yaqub Beg was defeated by the Chinese general Zuo Zongtang. However, the 'Ili Crisis' lasted until 1881, when the Treaty of St. Petersburg was signed, resulting in the return of most of the annexed territory to China, although Russia kept some of it and China had to pay indemnities to her and allow her to open up more consulates in the area. In 1884, Sinkiang officially became a province of China. Sinkiang fell to the Ma Clique of warlords during the chaos which followed the dissolution of the Qing Empire. An independent Republic of Sinkiang was recently established, but must survive being a bone of contention between the several expansionist powers of the area: Mongolia and a ressurgent Qing China see Sinkiang as part of their rightfull territory, while Turkestan sees the region as part of its sphere of influence.
French: La région de Xinjiang a joué un rôle fondamental dans le Grand Jeu opposant les grandes puissances de la région, cela en raison de sa situation géographique, à mi-chemin entre la Russie et l’Inde britannique. Les deux puissances installent simultanément des activités commerciales dans la région malgré l’interdiction mandchoue pesant sur le commerce européen. Selon des sources soviétiques, “les Britanniques sont les plus redoutés des deux peuples colonisateurs depuis leurs actes en Inde. Par ailleurs, Pékin est hantée par la peur d’une action de ces terribles colons dans le Turkestan oriental.” Pourtant les efforts de la Grande-Bretagne ne suffisent pas à empêcher la Russie de s’emparer du pouvoir dans la région. La Chine est par conséquent contrainte de signer un certain nombre de “traités inégaux” avec les pouvoirs occidentaux à l’issue des guerres de l’Opium. Il s’agit surtout du traité de Ili (1851), du protocole de Tacheng inclus dans le traité de Pékin (1860) et du traité de Tarbagatai (1864). La Chine cède ainsi plus de 90000 km² à la Russie sans compter des privilèges commerciaux et diplomatiques. A cette même période, la Chine perd une grande partie des territoires qu’elle occupe en Mandchourie, ceux-ci profitant une fois de plus aux Soviétiques. L’Etat chinois est en outre affaibli par de nombreux conflits internes dont la révolte de Taiping (1850-64), la seconde guerre de l’Opium (1857-60) et les révoltes islamiques de Yunnan (1855-1873) et de Shaanxi (1862-1873). Entre 1864 et 1877, les musulmans de Xinjiang se révoltent et forment un Etat indépendant qu’ils appellent la “Kashgarie”. Le pays est gouverné par Yukub Beg, un aventurier de Kokand, qui tente de maintenir de bonnes relations aussi bien avec la Russie que la Grande-Bretagne dans l’espoir qu’elles le protègent des inévitables attaques chinoises visant à reprendre le contrôle de la région. Les Russes profitent de la situation instable pour annexer la vallée d’Ili (1870-1871), prétextant qu’ils se doivent d’assurer l’ordre dans cette région voisine de leurs nouveaux territoires en Turkestan. En 1877, Yukub Beg est vaincu par le général chinois Zuo Zongtang, mais la crise de Ili se poursuit jusqu’en 1881, date à laquelle le traité de Saint-Pétersbourg rend à la Chine la plupart de ses territoires annexés. La Russie en conserve néanmoins quelques-uns et force la Chine à lui payer des indemnités ainsi qu’à ouvrir de nouveaux consulats dans la région. En 1884, la province Xinjiang est officiellement reconnue dépendante de la Chine. La lutte pour l’indépendance se poursuit malgré ces quelques avancées, aboutissant en 1933 à la création de la République du Turkestan oriental à Kachgar.
Italian: Sinkiang ha giocato un ruolo fondamentale nella grande partita fra i poteri più forti della regione, data la sua posizione fra la Russia e l'India inglese. Entrambe le potenze attivarono presto i loro commerci nella provincia, anche se Manciù impose un bando al commercio europeo in quell'area. Secondo la fonte sovietica, 'gli inglesi, col loro primato in India, erano i più temuti dei due e Pechino viveva nella costante paura di intrighi nel Turkestan orientale da parte di questi colonizzatori incalliti'. Tuttavia, nonostante gli sforzi inglesi, la Russia riuscì a ottenere il predominio nella zona. Come risultato dei diversi 'trattati iniqui' che la Cina fu costretta a firmare con le potenze occidentali dopo le guerre dell'oppio, nello specifico il trattato Ili (1851), il protocollo Tacheng del trattato di Pechino (1860) e il trattato di Tarbagatai (1864), la Cina dovette cedere quasi 350.000 metri quadrati di territorio alla Russia, oltre a offrire loro speciali privilegi commerciali e il diritto di collocare dei consoli nell'area. Nello stesso periodo, la Cina accusò numerose perdite territoriali in favore dei russi in Manciuria. Lo stato indebolito della Cina dopo la ribellione di Taiping (1850-1864), la seconda guerra dell'oppio (1857-1860) e le ribellioni Muslim a Yunnan (1855-1873) e Shaanxi (1862-1873) prepararono il terreno per la fase successiva della partita. Fra il 1864 e il 1877, i musulmani in Sinkiang si ribellarono e fondarono uno stato indipendente, noto col nome di 'Kashgaria', sotto la guida dell'avventuriero di Kokand, Yaqub Beg, che cercò di mantenere buoni rapporti sia con Inghilterra che Russia, nella speranza di ottenere da loro protezione contro l'inevitabile tentativo da parte cinese di riportare la zona e i suoi abitanti sotto il controllo della dinastia Qing. A queste instabili condizioni, i russi procederono ad annettere la valle Ili nel 1870-71, giustificandosi con la necessità di far rispettare l'ordine e la legge in quell'area adiacente il loro territorio appena conquistato nel Turkestan russo. Nel 1877, Yaqub Beg venne sconfitto dal generale cinese Zuo Zongtang. Tuttavia, la 'crisi Ili' durò fino al 1881, quando venne siglato il trattato di San Pietroburgo, che ebbe come risultato il ritorno della maggior parte del territorio annesso alla Cina, anche se la Russia ne tenne un po' per sé e la Cina dovette pagarle delle indennità e permetterle di aprire altri consolati nella zona. Nel 1884, Sinkiang fu proclamata ufficialmente provincia della Cina. Ad ogni modo, il desiderio di lotta per l'indipendenza rimase, e nel 1933, in Kashgar, fu fondata la repubblica indipendente del Turkestan orientale.
Spanish: Xinjiang jugó un papel crucial en la 'Gran Partida' entre las potencias principales de la región, localizada como estaba entre Rusia y la India británica. Pronto, ambas potencias emprendieron actividades comerciales en la provincia, aunque los manchúes habían impuesto una prohibición al comercio europeo en la zona. Según una fuente soviética, 'los británicos, con su historial en la India, eran los más temidos de los dos, y Pekín vivía en un temor constante a las intrigas de estos incorregibles colonizadores en el Turquestán oriental.' Sin embargo, y a pesar de los esfuerzos británicos, Rusia acabó llevando la delantera en la zona. Como resultado de varios 'tratados desiguales' que China se vio obligada a firmar con las potencias occidentales tras las Guerras del Opio (concretamente el Tratado de Ili de 1851, el Protocolo Tacheng de las Convenciones de Pekín de 1860 y el Tratado de Tarbagatai de 1864), China tuvo que hacer entrega de 560.000 kilómetros cuadrados de su territorio a Rusia, así como conceder a los rusos privilegios comerciales especiales y el derecho a establecer consulados en la zona. Al mismo tiempo, China sufrió enormes pérdidas territoriales a manos rusas en Manchuria. El estado de debilitamiento de China como consecuencia de la Rebelión de los Taiping(1850-64), la Segunda Guerra del Opio (1857-60) y las rebeliones musulmanas en Yunnan (1855-1873) y Shaanxi (1862-1873) establecieron las condiciones para la siguiente fase de la partida. Entre 1864 y 1877, los musulmanes de Xinjiang se rebelaron y fundaron un estado independiente que pasó a ser conocido como 'Kashgaria', bajo el liderazgo del aventurero Kokand Yaqub Beg, que intentó mantener buenas relaciones tanto con Gran Bretaña como con Rusia, con la esperanza de que pudiesen protegerle del inevitable intento chino de devolver la zona y a sus pobladores al control de la dinastía Qing. En estas condiciones de inestabilidad, los rusos procedieron a anexionarse el Valle de Ili en 1870-71, dando como razón para ello el mantenimiento de la ley y el orden en esta zona adyacente al recién conquistado territorio del Turquestán ruso. En 1877, Yaqub Beg fue derrotado por el general chino Zuo Zongtang. Sin embargo, la 'Crisis de Ili' duró hasta 1881, cuando se firmó el Tratado de San Petersburgo que dio como resultado la devolución a China de la mayor parte de los territorios anexionados, aunque Rusia se quedó con parte de los mismos y China tuvo que pagarle indemnizaciones y permitirle abrir más consulados en la zona. En 1884, Xinjiang se convirtió de manera oficial en una provincia china. Sin embargo, los esfuerzos por independizarse continuaron, y en 1933 se fundó en Kashgar una República Independiente del Turquestán Oriental.
German: Xinjiang spielte im ’Great Game’ der großen regionalen Mächte eine bedeutende Rolle, da es sich zwischen Russland und dem britischen Indien befand. Obwohl die Mandschus europäische Handelsaktivitäten in der Region mit einem Bann belegt hatten, trieben beide Mächte in dieser Provinz schon bald regen Handel. Laut einer sowjetischen Quelle 'waren die Briten aufgrund ihres Rufs in Indien die gefürchteteren der beiden Mächte, und Peking lebte aus Furcht vor Intrigen in Ostturkestan durch diese unverbesserlichen Expansionisten in ständiger Angst'. Die Russen gewannen in der Region trotz britischer Bemühungen schließlich die Oberhand. Als Konsequenz der 'ungerechten Verträge', zu deren Unterschrift die westlichen Mächte China nach den Opiumkriegen zwangen (dabei sind besonders der Vertrag von Ili (1851), das Dacheng-Protokoll des Vertrags von Peking (1860) und der Vertrag von Tarbagatai (1864) zu nennen), musste es über 560.000 Quadratkilometer seines Territoriums an Russland abtreten sowie den Russen spezielle Handelsprivilegien und das Recht einräumen, Konsuln in der Region zu stationieren. Gleichzeitig musste China in der Mandschurei massive Gebietsverluste an Russland in Kauf nehmen. Chinas Staat, der wegen der Taiping-Rebellion (1850-64), des zweiten Opiumkriegs (1857-60) sowie den Moslemaufständen in Yunnan (1855-1873) und Shaanxi (1862-1873) geschwächt war, schuf die Voraussetzung für die nächste 'Spielphase': Zwischen 1864 und 1877 erhoben sich die Moslems in Xinjiang und errichteten unter der Führung des kokandischen Abenteurers Yaqub Beg einen unabhängigen Staat, der als 'Kashgar' bekannt werden sollte. Yaqub Beg versuchte, sowohl mit den Briten, als auch mit den Russen gute Beziehungen zu unterhalten, da er hoffte, dass ihn diese Staaten gegen den unvermeidlichen Versuch Chinas würden schützen können, die Region und ihre Bewohner erneut unter die Herrschaft der Qing-Dynastie zu bringen. In dieser unsicheren Lage annektierten die Russen 1870/71 das Ili-Tal und begründeten dies mit dem Bedürfnis, in diesem Gebiet, das an das von Russland gerade eroberte Turkistan grenzt, für Recht und Ordnung sorgen zu müssen. 1877 wurde Yaqub Beg vom chinesischen General Zuo Zongtang besiegt. Die 'Ili-Krise' setzte sich dennoch bis zur Unterzeichnung des Vertrags von St. Petersburg im Jahr 1881 fort, in dem China der Großteil des annektierten Gebiets zurückgegeben wurde, obwohl Russland ein Teil des Gebiets behielt, sich von China Schadenersatz zahlen ließ und China die Einrichtung weiterer Konsulate in der Region akzeptieren musste. 1884 wurde Xinjiang offiziell zur chinesischen Provinz. Das Streben nach Unabhängigkeit war jedoch keineswegs erstorben und so wurde 1933 in Kaschgar die Unabhängige Republik Turkistan ausgerufen.

English: Seeing the continuing discrimination of their people under the dual monarchy of Austria-Hungary, Slovakian politicians and intellectuals were convinced that only joining with the Czechs could lead the way out of their national misery. Representatives of emigrant Slovaks in the USA agreed with the Czech emigrant politicians Tomás Garrigue Masaryk, Eduard Benes, and Slovak general Milan Rastislav Stefanik on a united state of Czechs and Slovaks to be created after the war. But the victory of the Central Powers in the Weltkrieg destroyed all hopes for a final dissolution of the hated dual monarchy. Slovakia soon find itself target of a most brutal Hungarification campaign, aimed at nothing less but total destruction of Slovaks as nation. But thanks to outside intervention Slovakian nation was saved from its extermination and new independent slovak state has arisen on the map of the Central Europe. Now the big question is what it will do with it’s newly reclaimed freedom. Will the Slovaks become loyal to the German Empire or will Russian influence will be stronger? Will the Hungarians reconquer it? Or will the syndicalists rise here to start a domino effect in Eastern Europe? Only time will tell.
French: La discrimination permanente du peuple slovaque sous la monarchie austro-hongroise pousse politiciens et intellectuels slovaques à s’unir aux Tchèques dans l’espoir de sortir enfin de la répression. Les représentants des immigrants slovaques aux Etats-Unis conviennent d’une union tchécoslovaque avec les nationalistes tchèques Thomás Garrigue Masaryk et Edvard Beneš. Le pays ainsi créé devient officiellement la République indépendante de Tchécoslovaquie à Prague, en 1918. Après plus de mille ans de domination étrangère, les Slovaques, qui constituent 30 pour cent de la population tchécoslovaque, vivent enfin sous un gouvernement indépendant dans une égalité totale avec les Tchèques. Mais la prédominance tchèque soulève rapidement des conflits internes se manifestant notamment dans la mise en place de structures centralisées. Le principal mouvement anti-tchèque est le parti catholique conservateur du peuple slovaque (SPP) qui appelle à une plus grande autonomie. Après le traité de Munich de 1938, les régions tchécoslovaques des Sudètes sont cédées à l’Allemagne et le SPP profite de la faiblesse du gouvernement de Prague pour fédéraliser totalement la Tchécoslovaquie. En mars 1939, l’Allemagne rompt le traité de Munich et envahit la partie tchèque du pays qu’elle transforme aussitôt en “Reichsprotektorat Böhmen und Mähren” (Protectorat de Bohème et Moravie).  La veille, la Slovaquie avait déclaré son indépendance sur l’appel d’Adolf Hitler. La Slovaquie devient dès lors un vassal de l’Allemagne, bien que son indépendance soit officiellement reconnue par 25 pays dont la Grande-Bretagne, la France et l’Union Soviétique. Le gouvernement dirigé par le prêtre catholique Jozef Tiso, adopte une politique conservatrice et autoritaire sur ordre de Berlin.
Italian: Vedendo la continua discriminazione delle loro genti sotto la doppia monarchia austro-ungarica, i politici e gli intellettuali slovacchi erano convinti che solo unendosi ai cechi avrebbero potuto porre fine alla loro miseria nazionale. I rappresentanti degli immigrati slovacchi negli Stati Uniti, concordarono con i nazionalisti cechi Thomás Garrigue Masaryk ed Eduard Benes, sulla necessità di uno stato unito di cechi e slovacchi. Questo nuovo paese, venne proclamato repubblica indipendente col nome di Cecoslovacchia nel 1918 a Praga. Dopo oltre 1.000 anni di governo straniero, gli slovacchi, componenti circa il 30 percento della popolazione cecoslovacca, si ritrovavano insieme ai cechi in uno stato autonomo. Ma ben presto si vennero a creare rivolte circa il ruolo predominante dei cechi, che trovò, fra le tante cose, la sua espressione nella fondazione di strutture centralizzate. Il potere più forte della resistenza anti-ceca era rappresentato dal partito popolare slovacco (SPP), conservatore e cattolico, il quale chiedeva un'autonomia più estesa. Quando, dopo il trattato di Monaco (1938), le regioni meridionali della Cecoslovacchia vennero cedute alla Germania, il SPP approfittò dell'occasione e sfruttando la grossa debolezza del governo di Praga raggiunse la federalizzazione della Cecoslovacchia. Nel marzo 1939, la Germania ruppe il patto di Monaco occupando la parte ceca del paese e trasformandola nel 'Reichsprotektorat Böhmen und Mähren' (protettorato di Bohemia e Moravia). Un giorno prima, per ordine di Adolf Hitler, la Slovacchia aveva potuto proclamare la propria indipendenza. Una volta indipendente, la Slovacchia diveniva di fatto un vassallo della Germania, anche se il nuovo paese venne riconosciuto da 25 stati fra cui Inghilterra, Francia e Unione Sovietica. Il governo del primo ministro Jozef Tisos, un prete cattolico, seguì, sotto l'attento sguardo di Berlino, una politica conservatrice autoritaria.
Spanish: A la vista de la continuada discriminación que sufría su gente bajo la doble corona de Austria-Hungría, los políticos e intelectuales eslovacos estaban convencidos de que la unión con los checos era la única manera de salir de su miseria nacional. Representantes de eslovacos emigrados a los Estados Unidos acordaron con los nacionalistas checos Tomás Garrigue Masaryk y Edvard Benes un estado único para checos y eslovacos. El nuevo país se proclamó república independiente en Praga en 1918 con el nombre de Checoslovaquia. Tras más de 1000 años de dominio extranjero, los eslovacos, que suponían alrededor del 30 por ciento de la población total de Checoslovaquia, se unieron a los checos como iguales en un estado autónomo. Pero pronto se sucedieron los disturbios a causa del predominio de los checos, que se expresaba principalmente en el establecimiento de estructuras centralizadas. La principal fuerza de resistencia anticheca era el católico conservador Partido del Pueblo Eslovaco, que exigía una amplia autonomía. Cuando, tras los Acuerdos de Munich de 1938, se cedieron a Alemania las regiones de los Sudetes, el Partido del Pueblo Eslovaco aprovechó la oportunidad para explotar la extrema debilidad del gobierno de Praga y lograr la federalización de Checoslovaquia. En marzo de 1939, Alemania violó el Pacto de Munich y ocupó la parte checa del país, convirtiéndola en el 'Reichsprotektorat Böhmen und Mähren' (Protectorado de Bohemia y Moravia). Un día antes, a la llamada de Adolf Hitler, Eslovaquia había declarado su independencia. Formalmente independiente, Eslovaquia era un vasallo de hecho de Alemania, aunque el nuevo país fue reconocido por 25 estados, entre ellos Gran Bretaña, Francia y la Unión Soviética. El gobierno del Primer Ministro Jozef Tiso, un sacerdote católico, siguió una política autoritaria conservadora, supervisado de cerca por Berlín.
German: Angesichts der fortwährenden Diskriminierung ihrer Landsleute unter der österreichisch-ungarischen Doppelmonarchie waren die slowakischen Politiker davon überzeugt, dass nur ein Anschluss an die Tschechei sie aus ihrer nationalen Misere würde führen können. Repräsentanten der in die U.S.A. immigrierten Slowaken stimmten mit den Tschechischen Nationalisten Thomás Garrigue Masaryk und Eduard Benes bezüglich der Errichtung eines vereinigten Staates der Tschechen und Slowaken überein. Dieses neue Land wurde 1918 in Prag als unabhängige Republik proklamiert. Nach über 1000 Jahren der Fremdbestimmung wurden die Slowaken, die etwa 30 Prozent der gesamten tschechoslowakischen Bevölkerung ausmachten, als gleichberechtigte Bürger eines autonomen Staats angesehen. Bald jedoch machte sich aufgrund der Vorherrschaft der Tschechen Unmut breit, die sich unter anderem in der Einrichtung zentralistischer Strukturen manifestierte. Die treibende Kraft hinter dem anti-tschechischen Widerstand war die katholisch-konservative Slowakische Volkspartei, welche nach umfassender Autonomie strebte. Als 1938 nach dem Vertrag von München das Sudetenland an Deutschland abgetreten wurde, nahm die Slowakische Volkspartei die Gunst der Stunde war, nutzte die Hilflosigkeit der Prager Regierung aus und erreichte die Föderalisierung der Tschechoslowakei. Im März 1939 brach Deutschland den Vertrag von München, besetzte den tschechischen Teil des Landes und benannte es in das 'Reichsprotektorat Böhmen und Mähren' um. Ein Tag zuvor hatte die Slowakei nach Aufforderung Hillers ihre Unabhängigkeit erklärt. Trotz ihrer formellen Unabhängigkeit war die Slowakei tatsächlich nur ein Vasall Deutschlands, obwohl sie von 25 Staaten, darunter Großbritannien, Frankreich und die Sowjetunion, anerkannt wurde. Die Regierung des Premierministers Jozef Tisos ging unter strenger Beobachtung Berlins, einer konservativen, autoritären Politik nach.
